Maryland State Superintendent of Schools Karen Salmon announced the closure of all public schools in Maryland, including Charles County Public Schools (CCPS), effective Monday, March 16 through Friday, May 15. The closing is part of the state’s efforts to limit the spread of the Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19).
All CCPS activities, events and athletics are canceled during the closure. Until schools reopen, all school-related activities and meetings are canceled. CCPS is not making any decisions about graduation or other activities beyond May 15.
April 17 Video Update from Dr. Hill
Your browser does not support the video tag.
Distance Learning
On Friday, April 17, printed distance learning packets for the next two weeks of lesson plans will be at meal sites. Meal site locations are open Monday through Friday from 11 a.m. to 1 p.m. Meal sites will have all grade level/Apex Learning course packets with the exception of a few secondary math and science courses, and packets for English Learners. Packets for the following will only be available at Maurice J. McDonough and Westlake high schools.
Physics
Algebra with trigonometry and statistics
Advanced algebra with trigonometry
Pre-calculus
Introduction to advanced math
All packets for English learners
Distance learning packets are available online on the Elementary Distance Learning webpage and the Middle and High School Distance Learning Packets webpage.
Starting Wednesday, April 15 teachers will begin to use Microsoft Teams, a collaborative learning tool that features a classroom set up in Microsoft Office 365. Click here to read more about CCPS implementing Teams.
Laptop request deadline is April 24
The deadline for parents to request a laptop for their child to use for distance learning is Friday, April 24. The CCPS technology department is still working to configure more than 5,000 laptops requested. Principals will contact parents for laptop pick up as soon as their child’s laptop is ready. Parents can request laptops by completing a Student Technology Survey form.
Internet Access
CCPS has partnered with AT&T FirstNet to offer free, temporary internet access in the front parking lots of Piccowaxen Middle School, Matthew Henson Middle School, T.C. Martin Elementary School and Mt. Hope/Nanjemoy Elementary School. CCPS chose the hotspot locations using information from its recent student technology survey, Comcast and Verizon hotspot maps, and a recent broadband survey county government conducted to determine the areas in highest need. Click here to read more about the temporary internet access.
Mental Health Resources
CCPS school psychologists are available to speak with parents and guardians who need assistance during this time. Call 240-776-5802 from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. Monday through Friday to speak with a school psychologist Our psychologists are mental health professionals, however, calls do not constitute a counseling relationship, should not be considered confidential and topics of conversation should focus on educationally relevant topics related to COVID-19. Local, State and National resources also available. Mental Health Resources
AskCCPS
To limit the possible spread of the coronavirus (COVID-19), CCPS 12-month employees assigned to the Jesse L. Starkey Administration Building are teleworking at the discretion of their supervisors. Some 12-month employees are working on site to support CCPS business operations. The Starkey Building switchboard, 301-932-6610 and 301-870-3814, is closed to the public.
Parents, staff and community members in need of assistance visit the CCPS website at ccboe.com and look for the AskCCPS menu button located under the photo slideshow. AskCCPS is a help-desk for students, staff, parents and the community. The system features two areas for questions – general questions, and technology support. CCPS staff are monitoring the system and will respond within 24 hours to inquiries as they are received, Monday through Friday. A direct link to AskCCPS is ccboe.com/askccps.
March 27 Letter from Superintendent to Parents
March 27, 2020
Dear Parents and Guardians:
I’m sure by now you’ve heard this time described as “uncharted territory,” and it is. As the school closure extends through April 24, I want to let you know how the next couple of weeks of instruction will look in Charles County Public Schools (CCPS).
Third quarter report cards
Maryland public schools were initially closed from March 16 to 27 in an effort to slow the spread of coronavirus (COVID-19). The third quarter marking period ended March 13 when Gov. Larry Hogan declared a state of emergency. Third quarter report cards will be mailed to middle and high school students on April 7, and report cards for elementary school students will be posted on ParentVue on April 7. Elementary school parents who are unable to access ParentVue can email their child’s school principal to receive a paper copy of the report card in the mail.
Distance learning
CCPS content specialists have been working to develop instruction that classroom and special education teachers can assign to students while schools are closed. Teachers will spend the next week preparing and emailing students at their StudentVue account to give them further instructions. Teachers are considering equity and consistency, as well as the needs of students in special education programs and those who are in the English Learners (EL) program.
Assignments should be available for students on Friday, April 3. Teachers at all grade levels are establishing “office hours” and will let students know when they can be reached to answer questions.
There are two ways for students to receive assignments. Much like accessing the optional learning resources available to students over the past two weeks, students can access assignments online and in paper packets.
The paper version of the assignments will be available for pick up at the 11 CCPS meal sites between 11 a.m. to 1 p.m. Monday through Friday. While students are required to be present to receive meals, they do not have to be at the site to pick up the packets. For paper assignments, teachers will ask students to keep a “portfolio.” Students should keep all their paper work together and once schools open, they can bring it in to receive grades.
Elementary school students can access assignments at www.ccboe.com. Middle and high school students will use Apex Learning, which provides digital curriculum. High school students enrolled in the school system’s Virtual Academy already use Apex to complete coursework. Special education teachers will review all student IEPs in their caseload and use Goalbook, an online platform for teachers and students that focuses on individual learning goals.
Technology access
Students received a survey on March 13 to determine their access to the internet and/or technology devices. Students who don’t have a device to complete work may be able to borrow one from the CCPS technology department. Technology staff will begin the process of distributing laptops next week to students who need them.
CCPS has partnered with AT&T FirstNet to offer free, temporary internet access in the front parking lots of Piccowaxen Middle School, Matthew Henson Middle School, T.C. Martin Elementary School and Mt. Hope/Nanjemoy Elementary School. CCPS chose the hotspot locations using information from its recent student technology survey, Comcast and Verizon hotspot maps, and a recent broadband survey county government conducted to determine the areas in highest need.
We are indeed in uncharted territory, but we remain steadfast in providing our students with the best education possible. With your help, our students’ commitment to learning and our staff’s dedication to teaching, we can weather these challenges together.
Sincerely,
Kimberly A. Hill, Ed.D.
Superintendent of Schools
March 26 Letter from Superintendent to Secondary Students
March 26, 2020
Dear CCPS middle and high school students,
It seems that day after day the ground under us shifts and we are faced with another challenge presented by coronavirus (COVID-19). I want to let you know where things stand in Charles County Public Schools (CCPS) as of today, now that the school closure has been extended through Friday, April 24.
On March 13, the last day of school before the initial closure, there were seven days left in the third marking period. We are not extending the marking period, so on March 30, teachers will finish and post third quarter grades. Report cards will be mailed Tuesday, April 7.
We are moving forward. Your teachers will spend the early part of next week previewing and reviewing distance learning lesson plans. By Thursday, your teachers will contact you through your StudentVue account to give you an overview at how instruction will look in the coming weeks. For now, we will focus on the four core subjects — English, math, science and social studies.
As secondary school students, you will use APEX, which provides digital curriculum. High school students enrolled at the Virtual Academy already use APEX to complete their coursework.
Many of you probably took a survey on March 13 asking if you had internet access and a device available at home. For those of you who don’t have a device, the CCPS technology department will likely have one for you to borrow. Your parents or guardians will be contacted with instructions on how to get a device to you. We’re working with AT&T to set up “hotspots” at some schools that will connect you to the internet from a vehicle.
If you don’t have internet at home, a device available to access the online assignments, or you prefer working with pen and paper, paper packets of the online assignments will be available at the 11 meal sites starting Friday, April 3. We ask that you keep the paper assignments together in a sort of “portfolio” that will be submitted to your teachers when the closure is lifted.
The work launching on April 3 will count toward a fourth quarter grade, but right now we are working out how grades will be given.
Until schools reopen, all school-related activities and meetings are canceled. We are not making any decisions about graduation or other activities beyond April 24 at this time.
On another note, I want you to remember you are students. Students seek out the most reliable information. Two trusted sources that have the most up-to-date information about COVID-19 are the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the World Health Organization.
For the latest information from CCPS, visit ccboe.com or find us on Twitter @ccps or Charles County Public Schools on Facebook.
Take care and I wish you and your family good health.
Sincerely,
Kimberly A. Hill, Ed.D.
Superintendent
March 25 Letter from Superintendent to Parents
March 25, 2020
Dear Parents and Guardians,
Today, Dr. Karen Salmon, the state superintendent of Maryland public schools, extended the school closure through April 24 in an effort to slow the spread of coronavirus (COVID-19).
Charles County Public Schools (CCPS) staff has been preparing to offer distance learning educational services to our more than 27,500 students.
In the coming week, we will be working with our teachers to provide the support they need to continue educational services and introduce online learning. We will be reviewing our activity and event schedules to determine what we need to reschedule or postpone. Although the state extended our school closure date until April 24, our reopening still depends on decisions made by the state superintendent.
Throughout the next four weeks, I will keep the school system’s communication to you transparent and frequent. There is a lot we do not know right now, but as we learn more, cancel, reschedule or add services, we will email the information to you, as well as post it on our website at www.ccboe.com, on the CCPS Facebook and Twitter accounts, and on our educational channels Comcast 96 and Verizon FiOS 12.
Thank you for your support over the past two weeks. Working together, we can manage the disruption the coronavirus (COVID-19) has had and lessen the impact on our children, staff and community.
Sincerely,
Kimberly A. Hill, Ed.D.
Superintendent of Schools
March 24 Letter from Superintendent to Parents
March 24, 2020
Dear Parents and Guardians,
Yesterday, Governor Larry Hogan held a press conference where he spoke about tightening restrictions on Maryland businesses to slow the spread of coronavirus (COVID-19).
Charles County Public Schools (CCPS), like all school systems in the state, is closed through March 27. We fully expect that the school closure will be extended, and I want to let you know how CCPS staff is preparing for the coming weeks.
If the school closure extends beyond March 27, CCPS plans to offer online and paper packet learning activities for all students. Teachers will be reaching out to students and their parents later this week to reconnect and to help them become acquainted with these learning activities. Teachers will help students who do not have access to the internet or a device at home to ensure instruction continues.
CCPS staff is working on plans for students who need additional support.
The school system will continue to provide meals to children 18 and younger at designated school sites. Children can receive three meals – a bagged lunch and dinner, and a breakfast pack for the following morning. The sites are open from 11 a.m. to 1 p.m., Monday through Friday, rain or shine. Paper packets of learning resources are available at the sites for those who do not have access to the online version or prefer to complete the activities on paper.
Building service staff has cleaned and sanitized our schools and buildings, which includes more than 4 million square feet.
We know this disruption to the school year is unusual and challenging, and parents and guardians may have concerns about their children’s social, emotional and behavioral development. CCPS psychologists can be reached between 10 a.m. and 3 p.m., Monday through Friday at 240-776-5802. Conversations should focus on educationally relevant topics.
We will update you as the week continues. Take care, wash your hands and stay home.
Sincerely,
Kimberly A. Hill, Ed.D.
Superintendent of Schools
March 20 Letter from Superintendent to Staff
March 20, 2020
Hello everyone,
First, let me tell you how proud I am of Charles County Public Schools (CCPS) and its employees. We have risen to the challenges presented by the coronavirus or COVID-19 to ensure the safety of our children and staff. We have collectively done this without deviating from our core mission — to serve children and our community.
I know you have questions about what the future holds. Please don’t worry about deadlines right now. Things like portfolios, evaluations, grades, testing, and running records will all be taken care of as we learn more about when we can reopen schools. As of this morning, schools are closed until March 27. I fully expect the Governor to extend that date, but I do not have any reliable information about when that might be or for how long. As soon as we get additional information, we’ll share it with you.
I know you want to reconnect with your students, that’s who you are, and that’s what we do. When you reconnect, you need to do so in a way that protects you and your students. Synergy is the easiest and most secure method for communicating; please do not use texts or personal accounts. We are working to identify children and staff members who do not have access to the internet or an electronic device at home. Equity is in the front of our minds as we plan to reestablish instruction.
Secondary teachers are receiving emails from Apex – an online learning platform. Please wait for instructions from Amy Hollstein before responding to these emails. We will update everyone on instructional plans early next week once we receive further direction from the state.
The last few days have been challenging, and at the same time, rewarding. There are so many ways CCPS employees have gone above and beyond.
Our food and nutrition services workers have provided thousands of meals to children over the past five days. Next week, we are adding three new meal sites at J.C. Parks Elementary School, Dr. Samuel A. Mudd Elementary School and Piccowaxen Middle School to serve more families.
Our building services staff have cleaned and sanitized over four million square feet of space. Their work has assured me that when we reopen schools, you and our students will be returning to safe and clean environments.
Many teachers are providing schoolwork and keeping in touch with their students. We appreciate your efforts to keep children engaged. I have seen so many creative examples of distance learning on social media. I know your students appreciate your efforts to keep them connected during a time when their lives have been upended. Please remember that the state has not authorized us to assign instruction for grading. Any materials you send your students must be a voluntary learning opportunity.
The health and well being of our CCPS family is our top concern. Thank you for your willingness to lead during this unprecedented time. We continue to make decisions based on information that changes hourly.
I promise to stay in touch and keep you informed. Please monitor your email and the CCPS website, ccboe.com, for the most updated information.
Kim
March 19 Letter from Superintendent to Parents
March 19, 2020
Dear Parents/Guardians:
As of today, Charles County Public Schools (CCPS) remains closed through March 27. We are waiting for further direction from the state about any closure beyond March 27.
To limit the possible spread of the coronavirus (COVID-19), CCPS 12-month employees assigned to the Jesse L. Starkey Administration Building are teleworking at the discretion of their supervisors. Some 12-month employees are working on site to support CCPS business operations. The Starkey Building switchboard, 301-932-6610 and 301-870-3814, is closed to the public beginning tomorrow. The switchboard remains closed through Friday, March 27.
Parents, staff and community members in need of assistance can log on to the CCPS website at ccboe.com and look for the AskCCPS menu button located under the photo slideshow. AskCCPS is a help-desk for students, staff, parents and the community. The system features two areas for questions – general questions and technology requests. CCPS staff are monitoring the system and will respond within 24 hours to inquiries as they are received, Monday through Friday. A direct link to AskCCPS is ccboe.com/askccps.
Children in need of food can visit one of our eight meal locations serving breakfast, lunch, dinner and snack options, Monday through Friday from 11 a.m. to 1 p.m. A list of meal locations is available here. Paper learning packets are also available at the meal locations and are separated by grade level. We will open three additional meal sites on Tuesday, March 24 at Dr. Samuel A. Mudd and J.C. Parks elementary schools, and Piccowaxen Middle School.
CCPS has online instructional resources for students to access learning at home. Click the Online Instructional Resources slide from the home page of ccboe.com to access the materials. Parents can click here for a direct link. The materials are intended to provide children with activities to stay connected to learning while at home during the closure. If school closures go beyond March 27, CCPS will provide additional instructional resources and directions.
During the closure, CCPS is communicating with parents and staff via email, text notifications for text message subscribers, ccboe.com, the 24-hour information line at 301-934-7410, and CCPS social media outlets. Monitoring email and the CCPS website, ccboe.com, are the best ways to receive up-to-date information about the status of school.
We continue to work with the Charles County Department of Health, and local and state leaders as the COVID-19 pandemic evolves in Maryland. Please visit the CCPS website at ccboe.com for more ways to help your child cope with the impact of COVID-19. Mental health supports are in place for parents in need of assistance during the closure.
Thank you for your support as we all navigate trying times for our community.
Sincerely,
Kimberly A. Hill
Superintendent of Schools
March 17 Letter from superintendent to parents
March 17, 2020
Dear Parents and Guardians:
While schools are closed throughout the state in an effort to slow the spread of the coronavirus (COVID-19), Charles County Public Schools (CCPS) is committed to ensuring our parents and guardians have access to mental health supports related to concerns about COVID-19.
CCPS school psychologists are available to speak with parents and guardians who need assistance during this time. Call 240-776-5802 from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. Monday through Friday to speak with a school psychologist, starting Wednesday, March 18. Our psychologists are mental health professionals, however, calls do not constitute a counseling relationship, should not be considered confidential and topics of conversation should focus on educationally relevant topics related to COVID-19. Psychologists may refer parents and guardians in need of additional help to the Tri-County Youth Services Bureau (TCYSB) for mental health services.
Children need age-appropriate information and facts. Depending on their age, talk to your child about the seriousness of this illness and the steps they can take to prevent becoming ill or spreading an illness to others. Giving a child a sense of control can help ease their anxiety. The National Association of School Psychologists recommends the following:
Remain calm and reassuring.
Make yourself available.
Avoid excessive blaming.
Monitor television viewing and social media use.
Maintain a normal routine as much as possible.
Be honest and accurate.
Know the symptoms of COVID-19.
Talk about and model proper hygiene and healthy lifestyle choices that can prevent illness.
Please visit the CCPS website at www.ccboe.com for more ways to help your child cope with the impact COVID-19 has made on day-to-day life. The website is also where you can learn the latest information regarding the school closure as we receive it.
We continue to work with the Charles County Department of Health, and local and state leaders as the COVID-19 pandemic evolves. As of today, all Charles County public schools remain closed until March 27.
We will continue to keep you informed.
Sincerely,
Kimberly A. Hill, Ed.D.
Superintendent of Schools
March 12 Letter from Superintendent to Parents and Staff
March 12, 2020
Dear Parents/Guardians/Staff:
This afternoon, Maryland State Superintendent of Schools Karen Salmon announced the closure of all public schools in Maryland, including Charles County Public Schools (CCPS), effective Monday, March 16 to Friday, March 27. The closing is part of the state’s efforts to limit the spread of the Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19).
Schools are open tomorrow, Friday, March 13. CCPS has canceled all afterschool and evening activities scheduled for tomorrow. All CCPS activities, events and athletics are canceled during the two-week closure. Closing will allow for building services staff to deep clean all CCPS buildings.
CCPS administrative offices will remain open, and 12-month employees will report to work during the two-week closure. However, CCPS buildings are not open to the public during this time.
All other CCPS employees – those who are not 12-month employees – should not report to work between March 16 and March 20. Decisions about the week of March 23 to 27 will be announced at a later date.
CCPS instructional staff have created optional instructional activities for students to complete at home. CCPS will post a link to a distance learning website on Monday, March 16, at ccboe.com. CCPS plans to provide paper-based instructional resources for students who do not have technology access.
CCPS plans to offer free meals for children ages 18 and younger. Meals will be cold bagged lunches. CCPS will start offering meals to children under 18 on Monday, March 16. We will provide more details about the meal program and locations tomorrow.
Tomorrow, teachers will provide students with a short technology survey to complete at school. We will use survey responses to determine how many students have technology access at home, including the internet and what devices are available, in case CCPS needs to expand distance learning for students.
During the next week, CCPS will review options for making up days. CCPS has six make-up days available for use, including three inclement weather days built into the calendar and three scheduled days off for spring break.
We will keep parents and staff updated as more information becomes available.
Sincerely,
Kimberly A. Hill, Ed.D.
Superintendent of Schools
March 11 Letter from the Superintendent to Parents
March 11, 2020
Dear Parents/Guardians:
Today, the Maryland State Department of Education, in coordination with the Maryland Department of Health, advised Maryland public school systems to cancel out-of-state and international field trips and athletic events.
Starting tomorrow, Charles County Public Schools (CCPS) is canceling out-of-state field trips. We are also limiting out-of-state business travel by employees. We are not, at this time, canceling any trips or events occurring in Maryland. Student participation in field trips is optional and at the discretion of the parent or guardian. Please monitor the CCPS website at www.ccboe.com for any changes.
We are monitoring student and staff attendance daily, and conducting additional cleaning in buildings with higher levels of absences. We are also keeping staff and parents informed of preventative actions like frequent handwashing, covering coughs and sneezes, and encouraging students and staff to stay home if they are sick. We are reviewing and updating our emergency operations plans, which include how we would provide academic and food services to families if needed. By working together with other community agencies, our goal is to be prepared and avoid panic.
We continue to work with the Charles County Department of Health and rely on the expertise of their medical professionals to guide us as we make decisions. CCPS will coordinate with the health department before making any decision to cancel school or in-state activities. While there are confirmed cases of coronavirus in Maryland, there have been none reported in Charles County.
We are preparing for any possible situation related to coronavirus, both short- and long-term. I will continue to keep you informed.
Sincerely,
Kimberly A. Hill, Ed.D.
Superintendent of Schools
March 3 Letter from the Superintendent to Parents
March 3, 2020
Dear Parents/Guardians:
Charles County Public Schools (CCPS) continues to work closely with the Charles County Department of Health to monitor updates about the coronavirus (COVID-19). As of today, there are no confirmed COVID-19 cases in Charles County.
We take great pride in keeping children healthy and in school. One of the ways we help prevent illnesses is through daily cleaning at our schools and centers. Our building service staff cleans and disinfects our schools and centers each day, and even more frequently during cold and flu season. Additionally, if a school is experiencing a high level of student absences, building service staff disinfects with a misting fogger.
CCPS cleans all touchpoints in CCPS facilities with disinfectant. A touchpoint is any surface above the floor, including, but not limited to, restroom surfaces and fixtures, food consumption areas, classroom work surfaces and gym equipment.
A CCPS web page, https://www.ccboe.com/index.php/coronavirus-information, has the latest information about coronavirus and how it could affect our school system. We will continue to keep parents and staff updated.
Sincerely,
Kimberly A. Hill, Ed.D.
Superintendent of Schools
February 26 Letter from Superintendent to Parents
February 26, 2020
Dear Parents/Guardians:
We understand that there is increasing concern regarding the new virus COVID-19 (formerly referred to as novel coronavirus and 2019-nCoV) and its potential spread. There are no laboratory confirmed COVID-19 cases in the state of Maryland at this time. There is a low risk for contracting COVID-19 in Maryland and in the United States.
Charles County Public Schools and the Charles County Department of Health are writing this letter to provide a background of COVID-19 and the measures recommended by global, federal, state and local health organizations.
In general, people can protect themselves and others against respiratory viruses by taking the following precautions:
Wash your hands frequently with soap and water.
Cover your mouth and nose while coughing or sneezing.
Avoid close contact with people who are sick.
If you or your child is sick, stay home from work or school.
Avoid touching your eyes, nose or mouth with unwashed hands.
It is Charles County Public Schools practice that students need to be fever free (less than 100 degrees Fahrenheit without the use of fever-reducing medication) for at least 24 hours before returning to school after any illness.
It is not too late to get your flu shot. While the influenza vaccine does not protect against the coronavirus infection, it can help keep you and your family healthy during the flu season.
There is no vaccine for this virus at this time, and the Centers for Disease Control (CDC), the World Health Organization (WHO) and the Maryland Department of Health (MDH) have been monitoring, issuing and updating guidance regarding travel, business, general population and schools. To provide you with further information on COVID-19, the Maryland Department of Health’s Guidance for Schools about the novel coronavirus (COVID-19) is attached.
If you have any questions regarding COVID-19 and your child’s health, please contact your child’s physician, School Nurse Supervisor at 301-934-7346 or the Charles County Department of Health’s Infectious Disease Program at 301-609-6900, ext. 6025, Monday through Friday, 8 a.m. through 5 p.m., and ask to speak to a nurse.
We will keep you updated as conditions change. For the most up to date information, visit the CDC’s COVID-19 website at https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/ or MDH’s website at https://phpa.health.maryland.gov/Pages/Novel-coronavirus.aspx.
Sincerely,
Dr. Suzan Lowry, Health Officer Dr. Kimberly Hill, Superintendent of Schools
Guidance for Schools About COVID-19 from the Maryland Department of Health
Guidance for Schools About the Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19)
What is the concern about COVID-19? What is the concern about COVID-19?
There is an ongoing, international outbreak of a new virus, called COVID-19, formerly known as 2019-nCoV. While many of the early cases in this outbreak primarily involved people living in Wuhan City, China, Chinese health officials have now reported thousands of cases throughout China. This virus causes a respiratory illness which includes fever, cough, and shortness of breath, and in some cases, can be fatal. It is thought that infected people will develop symptoms 2 to 14 days after an exposure.
What is being done to address the COVID-19?
On arrival to the United States, travelers from China may be asked questions to determine if they need to undergo health screening. During the health screening, authorities check temperatures, symptoms, and ask about specific exposures in China. If travelers have concerning symptoms, they will be sent for medical evaluation. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) staff will provide health information cards to travelers that tell travelers what symptoms to look out for, and what to do if they develop symptoms within 14 days after leaving China. Some travelers might be asked to stay home from work or school for up to 14 days.
What are the symptoms that COVID-19 can cause?
Patients with COVID-19 have had mild to severe respiratory illness with fever, cough, and difficulty breathing.
How does the virus spread?
This virus probably originally emerged from an animal source but is now spreading from person-to­person. At this time, it is unclear how this virus is spreading between people; however other coronaviruses spread person-to-person via respiratory droplets created when an infected person coughs or sneezes (similar to how influenza and many other respiratory pathogens spread) and droplets infect another person.
What if a student traveled to China and has no symptoms? Can they come to school?
It depends on when the student was last in China. Students who arrived from China prior to February 4, 2020 and who are well (without symptoms) are not restricted from school or other activities. Because of the wider spread of the virus in China, potential exposures in China are now greater. Therefore, children who arrived from China on February 4 or later should stay home from school until it's been 14 days since they left China. After the 14 day period is over, those students are able to return to school with no restrictions on their activities.
What if a student has traveled to China and is sick with fever and respiratory symptoms?
If a student who has traveled in the last 14 days to China, develops fever or respiratory symptoms (especially cough or difficulty breathing), they should stay home from school and be assessed by their primary care provider. If the student does not have a primary care provider, schools should contact the local health department for further guidance.
What if a student has traveled to China and while in school becomes sick with fever and respiratory symptoms?
If a student who has traveled in the last 14 days to China develops fever or respiratory symptoms while at school, the local health department should be notified, and a parent/guardian should pick up the student immediately. The student should wear a surgical mask (if possible) and be placed in a safe isolation area visible to the school nurse or other school health services staff e.g. Licensed Practical Nurse (LPN) or school health aide (Certified Nursing Assistant) and separate from the rest of the health room. Ideally this is a private room with the door closed and visibility maintained.
If you become of aware of a student who recently traveled to China and develops fever or respiratory illness, call your local health department and they can assist with determining what additional evaluation is needed. At this time of the year, there are many possible causes for respiratory illness, and it is likely a medical visit for further evaluation (including laboratory testing) will be necessary.
What if a student is sick with fever and respiratory symptoms?
What if a student is sick with fever and respiratory symptoms? Any student with a fever, even without travel history, should stay home from school until fever-free for 24 hours without the use of fever-reducing medications according to the Maryland Communicable Disease Summary. Students reporting to the health room with fever should be asked about recent travel to China.
At this time, residents of Maryland are at low risk of becoming infected with COVID-19, unless they have recently traveled to China or have come in close contact with someone who was ill who recently traveled to China. Even if an ill student has traveled to Wuhan or another area of China, or has had contact with an ill person who has traveled there, their respiratory illness may be due to a variety of other more common causes, including influenza and other common respiratory pathogens.
Students reporting to the health room with fever should be asked about travel to China within the prior 14 days. Any student with a fever, even without travel history, should stay home from school until fever-free for 24 hours without the use of fever-reducing medications according to the Maryland Communicable Disease Summary.
